thread.title: China's Spring Airlines offering 'supermoon viewing' flights this September
thread.title_full: China's Spring Airlines offering 'supermoon viewing' flights this September | Daily Mail Online

author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: China's Spring Airlines offering 'supermoon viewing' flights this September
text:
7 shares 2
View
comments
Aspiring astronomers take note: September 27 is a spectacular day to view the supermoon.
In conjunction with the Mid-Autumn Festival, also known as the Moon Festival, Chinese budget carrier Spring Airlines is offering travellers the chance of an unobstructed view of it.
And this year is particularly special as it's the first time in more than 30 years that a supermoon and a total lunar eclipse will take place on the same day.
Chinese budget carrier, Spring Airlines, will offer more than 100 'moon-viewing' flights during the Mid-Autumn Festival
Between September 26 and September 28, Spring Airlines is scheduled to offer around 100 scenic 'supermoon viewing' flights.
The Moon Festival is traditionally a day of reunions for families and friends around China, who come together to eat mooncakes (a round pastry filled with either red bean or lotus seed paste) under the full moon.
 What was their beef? Tourist 'attacked in Venice restaurant... From smouldering sunsets to storms over a lighthouse: The... named top-rated property according to... Tip the porter, don't dress like a slob and NEVER take... 'Festivals are the days when homesickness is at its worst,' Yi Mao, the airline's head of marketing, explained to CNN . 'We hope that the moon-viewing flights will take care of the emotional needs of our customers who are still on the road during the festival.'
It's also important to note that despite ground weather conditions, passengers will be treated to a perfect view once the plane clears the clouds.
The celebration, which is also known as the Moon Festival, is traditionally a day of reuniting with family and friends - and for eating mooncake pastries
CNN has also reported that, according to the China Meteorological Administration, the supermoon will actually be closest to China on the 28th - though that won't make much difference to humans viewing it with their naked eye.
But for those eager to take in this once-in-a-lifetime astronomic event, you should probably book quickly, as many of Spring Airlines' festival-dedicated seats have already been sold.
However, for those lucky enough to snap up a coveted booking, there are some precautions to take to ensure the best view: If you're flying from China's north to south, sit on the left side of the aircraft.
Likewise, those flying south to north should sit on the right.
Read more: Spring Airlines sells moon-viewing flights - CNN.com
